entry.title: Advanced Programming week 8
entry.content:
Intro

Monty Hall problem
Morkov chain
Monte Carlo method

Inverse Transform Sampling

wiki

  • Technique to select a random value from an arbitrary CDF (or PDF)
  • Very efficient when it works analytically
  • Often good numerically but not always

IVT Algorithm

  1. select U from v[0,1] i.e. uniformly
  2. find the value X such that
    F(x)=U where F is the CDF
    i.e. solve $X=F^{-1}(U)$

example

cosider PDF: $p(x)=e^{-x}$ where $0<=x<\infty$

  1. Find CDF:
    $F(x)=1-e^{-x}$
  2. Invert CDF:
    $F^{-1}(U)=-log(1-U)$
  3. select a U and evaluate $F^{-1}(U)$

Rejection Sampling

wiki

  • suppose you have a method of sampling from some PDF, call it g(x) and you want to draw a sample from some other PDF, f(x)
  • if for some constant M, $f(x)<=Mg(x)$

REJ Algorithm

  1. sample X from g(x)
  2. calculte $\alpha$, the probability of accepting X
    $$\alpha=\frac{f(x)}{Mg(x)} \,\, (note \,\, 0<=\alpha<=1)$$
  3. sample U from U(0,1]
  4. if $\alpha$>=U accept, else reject
  5. repeat

entry.title: Algorithm Week 7
entry.content:
Priority Queue

DEF

  1. maintains a set S of elements, each associated with a numberic key value (d-values)
  2. Supports the following operation
  • ISERT(S,x): insert element x into S
  • MIN(S): Return element of S with smallest key
  • EXTERT-MIN(S): return element of S with smallest key and removes ot from S
  • DECREASE-KEY(S, x, k): decreases the value of x’s key to new value k

Implementations

  1. ARRAY:
  • unordered array of key values for all elements
    Initially key values set to $\infty$
  • INSERT or DECREASE-KEY: O(1)
    EXTERT-MIN: linear-time scan of array
  1. BINARY HEAP:
  • A binary tree (Almost complete)
    represented as an array

Heap as binary tree

-with n vertices, tree height O(lgn)

  • root: first element in array (i=1) A[i]
    PARENT(i)= $\lfloor \left.\frac i2\right. \rfloor$
    LEFT(i)= 2i
    RIGHT(i)= 2i+1
  • min-healp property
    key[PARENT(i)]<=key[i], for all i<1 other than root
    A[PARENT(i)]<=A[i]
  • INSERT:
    MIN-HEAP-INSERT(A, key)

O(lgn)

  • DECREASE-KEY:
    HEAP-DECREASE-KEY(A, i, key)

O(lgn)

  • EXTRACT-MIN:
    HEAP-EXTRACT-MIN(A)

MIN-HEAPIFY(A, i, n)

O(lgn)
CLRS, Section 6.5, pp.162-165

DIJKSTRA(G, w, s)

Fredman-tarjan

EXTER:
Fredman-tarjan
Fibonnacci heap

Bellman-Ford ALG

DEF

  • d[v]: Current best estimate of shorest path weight from s to v
  • $\pi$[v]: Parent of v
  • Initially: d[s] = 0, d[v] = $\infty$ for all v except s

BELLMAN-FORD(G, w, s)

O(VE)

INITILIZE-SINGLE-SOURCE(G, s)

RELAX(u, v, w)

Correctness

proof by induction
path:= $v_0 -> v_1 -> v_2 -> … -> v_j -> v_{j+1} -> v_k$

  • BASE CASE: what is $d[v_0]$? Initially d[s]=0
    what is S(S,$v_0$)? S(S,$v_0$)=0, O/W have a negative weight cycle
  • INDUCTIVE STEP: assume by induction that d[$v_j$]=S(s,$v_j$)
    after j rounds for j < i, Prove for d[$v_j$] !=
    [pic]

Shortest Paths in DAGs

common problem -> how fast?
IDEA: relax E edges on shorest paths in order so that all d-value converge after one pass
DAG-SHOREST-PATHS(G, w, s)

O(V+E)

MST: Minimum Spanning Tree

  • input: Connected, undirected, weighted G=(V,E)
    with weight function w, no constraint
  • output: a spanning tree T(connects all vertices) of minimum weight
    $$ w(T)=\sum_{(u,v)\in E} w(u,v)$$

Kruskal’s ALG (Greddy)

  1. sort edges by weight
  2. choose any edge with smallest weight
    put it into spanning tree building X
  3. successively consider remaining edges in order of increasing weight
    add edge to X if does not create cycle with other edges in X
  4. stop after |v|-1 edges added to X

KRUSKAL(G,m)

O(VE)
entry.summary:
Priority Queue

DEF

  1. maintains a set S of elements, each associated with a numberic key

entry.title: Advanced Programming Week 7
entry.content:
Union Find

ppt

Propability

Sample space and Events

  • let S = { all possible ordings 1…7 }
    S:”Sample Space”
  • let A be a subset of S, A is called an “event”
  • “union”: A $\cup$ B all outcomes in either A, B, or both
  • “intersection”: A $\cap$ B in both A and B
  • A and B are “disjoint” or “exclusive” if $A\cap B=\varnothing $
  • $A^c$ is A’s complement

    Axioms

  • 0<=P(A)<=1
  • P(S)=1
  • for any mutully exclusive events $ A_1,A_2,…,A_n $:
    $$ P(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i) = \sum_{i=1}^n P(A_i) $$
  • generally:
    $$P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)-P(A\cap B)$$

    Conditional Probability

    Probability of A given B
    $$ P(A|B) = \left.\frac{P(A\cup B)}{P(B)}\right. $$

Random Variables

  • In an experiment the unknown outcome is designeted as a random variable.

    Cumulative distribution function

  • For a random process, this outcome cannot be predicted, however we may know the probability of a perdict outcome. This is described by a cumulative distribution function (CDF)
    $$F(X)=P{ \mathbb{X} <= x }$$
    Where $\mathbb{X}$ is a given experiment and x denotes all possible outcomes.
    Laplace’s demon

Probability density function

  • The PDF is an equally common tool that serves the same purpose as the CDF.
  • The PDF is defined as the dervative of the distribution function
    $$ P(x)=\left.\frac{dP(x)}{dx}\right.$$
  • For a discrete sample space $P(x_i)$ is intepreted as $P(x_i)=P(\mathbb{X}=x_i)$
    Error function
    Mexican hat wavelet

PDF for continues random variable

$$P(x \in C)= \int_{C} P(x)dx$$
$$ P(a-\frac c2<=x<=a+\frac c2)=\int_{a-\frac c2}^{a+\frac c2} P(x)dx$$
$$ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} P(x)dx=1$$
$$ P(x)>=0\,\,\, \forall x$$

Expectation

The expected value of a random variable E[x] is defined as

  • discrete: $E[x]=\sum_i x_iP(x_i)$ where P(x) is the discrete PDF of x
  • continuous: $E[x]=\int_{-\infty}^\infty x_iP(x_i)$

Q: how do you draw sample from a PDF?
entry.summary:
Union Find

ppt

Propability

Sample space and Events<

entry.title: Algorithm Week 6
entry.content:
Review: DFS

  • input: G=(V,E), Directed or Undirected, in ADJ list format
  • output:
    • d[v]: discovery time
    • f[v]:finishing time
    • p[v]:parebt of v on DFS tree
  • time: O(V+E)

    Undirected Graphs:

  • tree edges
  • nontree edges (back edge)

    Directed Graphs

    4 typtes of edge S :
  1. Tree/forward Edge : d[u]<d[v]<f[v]<f[u]
  2. Back Edge : d[v]<d[u]<f[u]<f[v]
  3. Cross Edge : d[v]<f[v]<d[u]<f[u]

For tree, forward and cross edge (u,v):
f[v]<f[u] (\*) For back edge (u,v):f[u]<f[v] (**)`
So, back edges go from lower to higher finishing times f
can detect back edge and derermine if exists cycle in graph by compareing f times

Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAG)

  • DEF: let G=(V,E) be a directed graph H, G is acyclic if it contains no (directed) cycles.
  • Applicaton: Topological Sort

    Topological Sort

  • Given: A Directed Acyclic Graph G=(V,E)
  • Output: A list of G’s vertices $v_1,v_2,..,v_n$ such that all edges go from left to right
    V = Set of tasks, edge(u,v) means “do u before v”
  • no cycles, all edges have decreasing (high to low) finishing #’s by (*)
    order vertices by decreasing finishinf time f

TOPOLOGICAL-SORT(G)

TIME:O(V+E)

Correctness

NTS: if (u,v) belong to E, then f[v]<f[u]

proof:

when explore (u,v) what are the color of u and v?
Is v gray white or black?

Source Vertex

  • vertex with no incoming edges

    Sink Vertex

  • vertex with no outcoming edges

1st vertex in topological ordering is source and last is sink

Strongly Connected Components

  • DEF: two vertices u and v of a directed graph G are strongly connected if there is a path from u to v and a path from v to u
  • Partitions V in to disjoint sets of vertices called Strongly Connected Components(SCC)
  • A SCC is a maximal set of strongly connected vertices

    Clever (Tarjan): ideas

  1. consider transpose of G=(V,E): $G^T=(V,E^T)$ where $E^T={(v,u): (u,v) \in E}$
    observation: G and $G^T$ have the same SCCs
  2. Compdnent Graph
    $G^{SCC}=(V^{SCC},E^{SCC})$
    $V^{SCC}$: one vertex for each SCC in G
    $E^{SCC}$: has an edge if there is anedge between SCCs in G

pic

LEMMA: G^SCC is a DAG

proof:

let X and X’ be distinct SCCs in G
let $u,v \in X$, $u’,v’ \in X’$, and suppose there is a path from u to u’ in G, then there cannot be a path from v’ to v in G

How do we find a vertex in a sink SCC?

  • The vertex with highest finishing time in a DFS of a directed G is in a scource SCC.
  • NOTE: The vertex with lowest finishing time might not be in a sink
  • Take $G^T$, a source in G is a sink in $G^T$ and a sink in G is a source in $G^T$

SCC(G)

TIME: O(V+E)

Shortest Path

Weighted Directed Graphs

  • A weighted graph H is a directed together with a weight function
    $G=(V,E,w)$
  • shortest path from u to v is a path of minimum weight from u to v
  • shortest path weight from u to v:
    $\delta$(u,v)=min{ w(P) : P from u to v }

    When do shortest paths not exist?

    Negative edge weights
    Negative weight cycle:
    $\delta$(u,v) = $-\infty$
    if not reachable, $\delta$(u,v) = $+\infty$

Dijkstra’s Algorithm

  • input: ( G, w, S)
    • G=(V,E) Directed, ADJ
    • Weight function: w: E->R ( $\forall e \in E$ )( w(e)>=0 )
    • S in V, Source vertex
  • output:
    • d[v]: distance (weight of a shorest path from S to V)
      d[v] = $\delta$(S,V)
    • $\pi$[v]: parent of V on shorest paths tree

DIJKSTRA(G, w, s)

INITILIZE-SINGLE-SOURCE(G, s)

RELAX(u, v, w)

correctness
  • NTS: d[v]=$\delta$(s,v) when alg terminates
  • LEMMA: when u is delected from Q and added to S, d[v]=$\delta$(s,v)
  • proof:

    BASIS:
    At 1st iteraion, u=s, d[u]=d[s]=0, and $\delta$(s,s)=0 since no neg cycles
    INCUCTIVE STEP:
    suppose u has just been delected from Q, adn for all vertices w previously delected from Q, d[u]=$\delta$(s,u)
    NTS: d[u]=$\delta$(s,u)
    suppose, for contradiction, d[u]!=$\delta$(s,u)
    we know that relax sets d[v] to a finite value, there is always evdience of a path of that weight, d[v]>=$\delta$(s,v)
    and so if d[u]!=$\delta$(s,u) then d[u]>$\delta$(s,v)
    Thus,there is a shortest path from s to u with weight < d[u], call this path P.
    let y be the 1st vertex on P that is not in S(y might be u),
    and let x=$\pi$[y] be parent of y on P
    Then x=$\pi$[y] $\in$ S, so by IH d[x]=$\delta$(s,x)

Time analysis

Q: priority queue
|V| cost of insert + |V| cost of extract-min + O(E) * cost of decrease-key

  1. array for Q
    cost of insert: O(1)
    cost of extract-min: V-1
    cost of decrease-key: O(1)
    overall: $O(V^2)$

  2. Binary Heap for Q
    stored as an array
    cost of insert: O(lgV)
    cost of extract-min: O(lgV)
    cost of decrease-key: O(lgV)
    overall: $O( (V+E)lgV )$
entry.summary:
Review: DFS

  • input: G=(V,E), Directed or Undirected, in ADJ list format
  • output:
    • d[v]: dis
